newsitem.title: MOLDOVA: IFC invests in Moldovan fruit processer.
newsitem.headline: IFC invests in Moldovan fruit processer.

text.p: The International Finance Corporation signed agreements on Tuesday to provide $10 million loan and equity finance to the Incon group of companies, the leading Moldovan fruits and vegetables processing group.

"Agribusiness is a sector where Moldova has a comparative advantage, and Incon has a competitive advantage," Bastiaan Mohrmann, IFC Agribusiness Department official, who signed the agreement, told a news conference.

Incon will use financing from the IFC, the private-sector arm of the World Bank, to support a $22.6 million modernisation and expansion programme of the Cupcini, Ungheni and Floresti processing companies.
These three canneries, which make up the Incon group, produce 40 percent of Moldova's apple juice concentrate, consumer packed fruit juices and canned vegetable goods.
IFC's investment consists of a $8 million loan to Incon and equity of $2 million equivalent in the group.
The loan, the first by the IFC to the predominantly agricultural country, will be granted for a seven-year period, at Libor plus 4.5 percent, with a two-year grace period, with funds lent in marks.
The equity investment will make IFC the holder of 27 percent of Incon group, with the three canneries owning 70 percent, and management holding three percent.
Incon, set up in 1992, is in turn a major shareholder in each of the three canneries, which were initially sold for vouchers under Moldova's mass privatisation programme.
Incon group president Ion Sturza said the IFC's investment is a part of a larger project, worth a total $22.6 million. Almost $13 million has already been invested in this project.

Unipektin AG, a Swiss food-processing technology company, Ciba-Geigy, Russian-owned Donau-Bank AG, machinery producer FMC and Sweden's Tetra Laval have provided 30 percent of the total project investment.

"The agreement with the IFC will resolve three essential problems -- replenishing enterprise working capital, financing new equipment purchases, and rendering assistance to local agrarian companies in planting new orchards and obtaining chemical pesticides and herbicides," Sturza said.
Incon group's 1996 turnover was $43.4 million. It exports 30 percent of its goods to former Soviet republics and the rest to Europe and North America.
It plans to place its shares on international financial markets, Sturza said, without specifying any terms.
Mohrmann said the IFC was also considering investing in a wine-producer, leasing companies and a hotel in Moldova.
